As usual with proof by induction, show that the statement is true for n = 1 (or n = 0, if you like); assume it is true for n = k; then show that in that case it is true for n = k + 1. Here we’ll take n = 0 as the starting point: 1 x 2 x 3 = 6 so that is OK. Assume n = k works, so assume 6 divides (k + 1)(k + 2)(k + 3) Then put n = k + 1, which gives us (k + 2)(k + 3)(k + 4). We can rewrite this as (k + 1)(k + 2)(k + 3) + 3(k + 2)(k + 3). Then the first expression is assumed to divide by 6, and since either k + 2 or k + 3 is even, the second expression divides by 6 also. Hence if n = k works, n = k + 1 does also, which is the standard proof by induction. Since we know n = 0 works, we have shown that in that case so does n = 1, and in that case so does n = 2, and so on without limit.

There are two sets of cases in terms of a number [math]n[/math] divisible by [math]2[/math] and [math]3[/math]. The number is divisible by [math]2[/math] or not / even or not.The number is divisible by [math]3[/math] or not.Now let's assume that the number A. [math]n[/math] Is Even ie [math]n=2k[/math] ie [math]n+2=2(k+1)[/math] ie [math]n+2[/math] is divisible by [math]2[/math] B. [math]n[/math] Is Odd ie [math]n=2k+1[/math] ie [math]n+1=2k+1+1=2(k+1)[/math] ie [math]n+1[/math] is divisible by [math]2[/math] C. [math]n[/math] Is divisible by [math]3[/math] ie [math]n=3k[/math] ie [math]n+3=3k+3=3(k+1)[/math] ie [math]n+3[/math] is divisible by [math]3[/math]. D. [math]n[/math] is NOT DIVISIBLE by [math]3[/math] ie [math]n=3k+1[/math] or [math]n=3k+2[/math] ie [math]n+2=3k+1+2=3k+3[/math] OR [math]n+1=3k+2+1=3k+3[/math] respectively ie for both cases (of non divisible by [math]3[/math]), either [math]n+1[/math] or [math]n+2[/math] will be divisible by [math]3[/math]. So for any case of [math]n[/math] Atleast one factor of [math](n+1)(n+2)(n+3)[/math] will be divisible by [math]2[/math] And One factor of [math](n+1)(n+2)(n+3)[/math] will be divisible by [math]3[/math] So for any case of [math]n[/math], [math](n+1)(n+2)(n+3)[/math] will be divisible by [math]2×3=6[/math].
